sentences.zh: 張儀者，魏人也。

translations.text: Zhang Yi was a native of Wei.

sentences.zh: 始嘗與蘇秦俱事鬼谷先生，學術，蘇秦自以不及張儀。

translations.text: In his youth, he studied alongside Su Qin under Master Guigu, learning the arts of persuasion. Su Qin always considered himself inferior to Zhang Yi.

translations.text: Zhang Yi asked his wife, 'Is my tongue still there?'

sentences.zh: 其妻笑曰：「舌在也。」

translations.text: His wife laughed and said, 'It's still there.'

sentences.zh: 蘇秦已說趙王而得相約從親，然恐秦之攻諸侯，敗約後負，念莫可使用於秦者，乃使人微感張儀曰：「子始與蘇秦善，今秦已當路，子何不往游，以求通子之願？」

translations.text: After Su Qin had persuaded the King of Zhao and secured alliances with neighboring states, he worried that Qin might attack the other lords and break the alliances. Thinking of who might be useful in Qin, he secretly sent someone to tempt Zhang Yi: 'You were once close to Su Qin. Now Qin holds power—why not go there to seek your fortune?'

sentences.zh: 張儀於是之趙，上謁求見蘇秦。

translations.text: Zhang Yi then went to Zhao and requested an audience with Su Qin.

sentences.zh: 蘇秦乃誡門下人不為通，又使不得去者數日。

translations.text: Su Qin ordered his attendants not to let him in, and kept him waiting for several days.

sentences.zh: 已而見之，坐之堂下，賜仆妾之食。

translations.text: Finally, when he received him, he seated Zhang Yi in the main hall below the platform and served him the food given to servants and concubines.

translations.text: Then he repeatedly rebuked him: 'With your talents and abilities, you've brought yourself to this state of destitution and humiliation.

translations.text: I could speak on your behalf and make you wealthy and honored, but you're not worth saving.'

sentences.zh: 謝去之。

translations.text: He dismissed him.

sentences.zh: 張儀之來也，自以為故人，求益，反見辱，怒，念諸侯莫可事，獨秦能苦趙，乃遂入秦。

Zhang Yi then went to Zhao and requested an audience with Su Qin. Su Qin ordered his attendants not to let him in, and kept him waiting for several days. Finally, when he received him, he seated Zhang Yi in the main hall below the platform and served him the food given to servants and concubines. Then he repeatedly rebuked him: 'With your talents and abilities, you've brought yourself to this state of destitution and humiliation. Instead he was humiliated. Angry, he realized no other lord would take him in—only Qin could challenge Zhao. So he went to Qin.

sentences.zh: 蘇秦已而告其舍人曰：「張儀，天下賢士，吾殆弗如也。

translations.text: Later, Su Qin told his attendants: 'Zhang Yi is the most talented man in the world. I am no match for him.

sentences.zh: 今吾幸先用，而能用秦柄者，獨張儀可耳。

translations.text: Fortunately, I was employed first. The only one who can wield Qin's power is Zhang Yi.

sentences.zh: 然貧，無因以進。

translations.text: But he is poor and has no way to advance.

sentences.zh: 吾恐其樂小利而不遂，故召辱之，以激其意。

translations.text: I fear he might be content with small gains and not achieve great things, so I summoned and humiliated him to stir his ambition.

sentences.zh: 子為我陰奉之。」

translations.text: Secretly support him for me.'

sentences.zh: 乃言趙王，發金幣車馬，使人微隨張儀，與同宿舍，稍稍近就之，奉以車馬金錢，所欲用，為取給，而弗告。

translations.text: He spoke to the King of Zhao, who provided gold, coins, chariots, and horses. Su Qin sent people to secretly follow Zhang Yi, share his lodging, gradually get close to him, and provide him with chariots, horses, gold, and money—whatever he needed, without telling him who was behind it.

sentences.zh: 張儀遂得以見秦惠王。

translations.text: Thus Zhang Yi was able to meet King Hui of Qin.

sentences.zh: 惠王以為客卿，與謀伐諸侯。

translations.text: King Hui appointed him as a guest minister and consulted with him on attacking the feudal lords.

Thus Zhang Yi was able to meet King Hui of Qin. King Hui appointed him as a guest minister and consulted with him on attacking the feudal lords.

sentences.zh: 蘇秦之舍人乃辭去。

translations.text: Su Qin's attendants then took their leave.

sentences.zh: 張儀曰：「賴子得顯，方且報德，何故去也？」

translations.text: Zhang Yi said, 'Thanks to you I have become prominent. I was just about to repay your kindness—why are you leaving?'

sentences.zh: 舍人曰：「臣非知君，知君乃蘇君。

translations.text: The attendant said, 'I don't know you— I know Su Qin.

sentences.zh: 蘇君憂秦伐趙敗從約，以為非君莫能得秦柄，故感怒君，使臣陰奉給君資，盡蘇君之計謀。

translations.text: Su Qin worried that Qin would attack Zhao and break the alliances. He believed no one but you could control Qin's power, so he provoked you with anger and had me secretly support and provide for you, carrying out all of Su Qin's plans.

sentences.zh: 今君已用，請歸報。」

translations.text: Now that you are employed, let me return and report.'

sentences.zh: 張儀曰：「嗟乎，此在吾術中而不悟，吾不及蘇君明矣！

translations.text: Zhang Yi said, 'Alas, this was within my calculations but I didn't realize it. I am not as perceptive as Su Qin!

sentences.zh: 吾又新用，安能謀趙乎？

translations.text: I have just been appointed—how can I plot against Zhao?

sentences.zh: 為吾謝蘇君，蘇君之時，儀何敢言。

translations.text: Please apologize to Su Qin for me. While Su Qin lives, how dare I speak of such things.

sentences.zh: 且蘇君在，儀寧渠能乎！」

translations.text: As long as Su Qin lives, how could I possibly rival him!'

sentences.zh: 張儀既相秦，為文檄告楚相曰：「始吾從若飲，我不盜而璧，若笞我。

translations.text: Once Zhang Yi became prime minister of Qin, he sent a formal declaration to the prime minister of Chu: 'When I drank with you, I didn't steal your jade disc, yet you had me beaten.

sentences.zh: 若善守汝國，我顧且盜而城！」

translations.text: If you guard your state well, I might just steal your cities instead!'

Once Zhang Yi became prime minister of Qin, he sent a formal declaration to the prime minister of Chu: 'When I drank with you, I didn't steal your jade disc, yet you had me beaten. If you guard your state well, I might just steal your cities instead!'

sentences.zh: 苴蜀相攻擊，各來告急於秦。

translations.text: The rulers of Shu and Ba attacked each other and both appealed urgently to Qin for help.

sentences.zh: 秦惠王欲發兵以伐蜀，以為道險狹難至，而韓又來侵秦，秦惠王欲先伐韓，後伐蜀，恐不利，欲先伐蜀，恐韓襲秦之敝。

translations.text: King Hui of Qin wanted to send troops to attack Shu, but the road was dangerous and narrow, making it hard to reach. Meanwhile, Han was invading Qin. King Hui wanted to attack Han first, then Shu, but feared it would be disadvantageous. He wanted to attack Shu first, but worried Han would attack Qin while it was weakened.

sentences.zh: 猶豫未能決。

translations.text: He hesitated and couldn't decide.

sentences.zh: 司馬錯與張儀爭論於惠王之前，司馬錯欲伐蜀，張儀曰：「不如伐韓。」

translations.text: Sima Cuo and Zhang Yi debated before King Hui. Sima Cuo wanted to attack Shu; Zhang Yi said, 'Better to attack Han.'

sentences.zh: 王曰：「請聞其說。」

translations.text: The king said, 'Let me hear your reasoning.'

translations.text: Zhang Yi said: 'Ally with Wei and befriend Chu. Send troops down to Sanchuan, block the Shigu pass, occupy the Tunliu road. Cut off Nanyang from Wei, have Chu threaten Nandun. Qin attacks Xincheng and Yiyang to approach the suburbs of the two Zhous. Punish the Zhou king's crimes, invade Chu and Wei territory.

sentences.zh: 周自知不能救，九鼎寶器必出。

translations.text: Zhou will know it cannot save itself and will certainly surrender the Nine Tripods and precious vessels.

sentences.zh: 據九鼎，案圖籍，挾天子以令於天下，天下莫敢不聽，此王業也。

translations.text: Seize the Nine Tripods, control the maps and registers, hold the Son of Heaven hostage to command the world—none would dare disobey. This is the work of a true king.'

sentences.zh: 今夫蜀，西僻之國而戎翟之倫也，敝兵勞眾不足以成名，得其地不足以為利。

translations.text: 'Now Shu is a remote western land inhabited by barbarians. Wasting troops and exhausting the people there would not bring fame; gaining its territory would bring no benefit.'

sentences.zh: 臣聞爭名者於朝，爭利者於市。

translations.text: 'I have heard that those who compete for fame do so at court; those who compete for profit do so in the marketplace.'

sentences.zh: 今三川、周室，天下之朝市也，而王不爭焉，顧爭於戎翟，去王業遠矣。」

translations.text: 'Now Sanchuan and Zhou are the court and marketplace of the world. Yet Your Majesty does not compete there, instead competing with barbarians—that is far from true kingship.'

sentences.zh: 臣聞之，欲富國者務廣其地，欲彊兵者務富其民，欲王者務博其德，三資者備而王隨之矣。

translations.text: I have heard that those who wish to enrich their state must expand its territory; those who wish to strengthen their armies must enrich their people; those who wish to become kings must broaden their virtue. When these three are prepared, kingship will follow.'

sentences.zh: 今王地小民貧，故臣願先從事於易。

translations.text: 'Your Majesty's territory is small and the people poor, so I wish to start with what is easy.'

sentences.zh: 夫蜀，西僻之國也，而戎翟之長也，有桀紂之亂。

translations.text: 'Shu is a remote western land, the chief of the barbarians, plagued by chaos like Jie and Zhou.'

sentences.zh: 以秦攻之，譬如使豺狼逐群羊。

translations.text: 'For Qin to attack it would be like sending wolves to hunt sheep.'

sentences.zh: 得其地足以廣國，取其財足以富民繕兵，不傷眾而彼已服焉。

translations.text: 'Gaining its territory would expand our state; seizing its wealth would enrich our people and repair our armies. We wouldn't exhaust our troops, yet they would submit.'

sentences.zh: 拔一國而天下不以為暴，利盡西海而天下不以為貪，是我一舉而名實附也，而又有禁暴止亂之名。

translations.text: 'Conquering one state without the world calling it violent; benefiting from the western seas without being called greedy—this single action would bring both fame and profit, plus the reputation of suppressing violence and ending chaos.'

sentences.zh: 今攻韓，劫天子，惡名也，而未必利也，又有不義之名，而攻天下所不欲，危矣。

translations.text: 'Attacking Han would mean coercing the Son of Heaven—that brings evil fame and uncertain profit, plus the reputation of injustice. Attacking what the world opposes is dangerous.'

sentences.zh: 臣請謁其故：周，天下之宗室也；

translations.text: 'Let me explain the reasons: Zhou is the ancestral temple of the world;'

sentences.zh: 齊，韓之與國也。

translations.text: 'Qi is Han's ally.'

sentences.zh: 周自知失九鼎，韓自知亡三川，將二國并力合謀，以因乎齊、趙而求解乎楚、魏，以鼎與楚，以地與魏，王弗能止也。

translations.text: 'Zhou knows it will lose the Nine Tripods; Han knows it will lose Sanchuan. The two states will combine forces to seek relief through Qi and Zhao, giving the tripods to Chu and land to Wei. Your Majesty cannot stop this.'

sentences.zh: 此臣之所謂危也。

translations.text: 'This is what I call danger.'

sentences.zh: 惠王曰：「善，寡人請聽子。」

translations.text: King Hui said, 'Excellent. I will follow your advice.'

sentences.zh: 卒起兵伐蜀，十月，取之，遂定蜀，貶蜀王更號為侯，而使陳莊相蜀。

translations.text: He finally raised troops to attack Shu. In ten months they took it, pacified Shu, demoted the king of Shu to a marquis, and appointed Chen Zhuang as prime minister of Shu.

sentences.zh: 蜀既屬秦，秦以益彊，富厚，輕諸侯。

translations.text: With Shu now belonging to Qin, Qin grew even stronger and wealthier, looking down on the other feudal lords.

In ten months they took it, pacified Shu, demoted the king of Shu to a marquis, and appointed Chen Zhuang as prime minister of Shu. With Shu now belonging to Qin, Qin grew even stronger and wealthier, looking down on the other feudal lords.

sentences.zh: 秦惠王十年，使公子華與張儀圍蒲陽，降之。

translations.text: In the tenth year of King Hui's reign, he sent Prince Hua and Zhang Yi to besiege Puyang, which surrendered.

sentences.zh: 儀因言秦復與魏，而使公子繇質於魏。

translations.text: Zhang Yi then proposed that Qin reconcile with Wei and send Prince You as hostage to Wei.

sentences.zh: 儀因說魏王曰：「秦王之遇魏甚厚，魏不可以無禮。」

translations.text: Zhang Yi then persuaded the King of Wei: 'The King of Qin treats Wei very generously. Wei cannot be discourteous.'

sentences.zh: 魏因入上郡、少梁，謝秦惠王。

translations.text: Wei therefore ceded Shangdun and Shaoliang to thank King Hui of Qin.

sentences.zh: 惠王乃以張儀為相，更名少梁曰夏陽。

translations.text: King Hui then appointed Zhang Yi as prime minister and renamed Shaoliang to Xiayang.

In the tenth year of King Hui's reign, he sent Prince Hua and Zhang Yi to besiege Puyang, which surrendered. Zhang Yi then proposed that Qin reconcile with Wei and send Prince You as hostage to Wei. Zhang Yi then persuaded the King of Wei: 'The King of Qin treats Wei very generously. Wei cannot be discourteous.' Wei therefore ceded Shangdun and Shaoliang to thank King Hui of Qin. King Hui then appointed Zhang Yi as prime minister and renamed Shaoliang to Xiayang.

sentences.zh: 儀相秦四歲，立惠王為王。

translations.text: Zhang Yi served as Qin prime minister four years, established King Hui as king.

sentences.zh: 居一歲，為秦將，取陜。

translations.text: After one year, he served as Qin's general and took Xie.

sentences.zh: 筑上郡塞。

translations.text: He built fortifications at Shangdun.
Zhang Yi served as Qin prime minister four years, established King Hui as king. After one year, he served as Qin's general and took Xie. He built fortifications at Shangdun.

sentences.zh: 其後二年，使與齊、楚之相會齧桑。

translations.text: Two years later, he met with the prime ministers of Qi and Chu at Yaosang.

sentences.zh: 東還而免相，相魏以為秦，欲令魏先事秦而諸侯效之。

translations.text: On his return east, he was dismissed as prime minister. He became prime minister of Wei to serve Qin, hoping Wei would submit to Qin first so other lords would follow.

sentences.zh: 魏王不肯聽儀。

translations.text: The King of Wei refused to listen to Zhang Yi.

sentences.zh: 秦王怒，伐取魏之曲沃、平周，復陰厚張儀益甚。

translations.text: The King of Qin was angry and attacked Wei's Quwo and Pingzhou. He secretly increased his support for Zhang Yi even more.

sentences.zh: 張儀慚，無以歸報。

translations.text: Zhang Yi was ashamed and had nothing to show for his efforts.

sentences.zh: 留魏四歲而魏襄王卒，哀王立。

translations.text: He remained in Wei four years until King Xiang of Wei died and King Ai ascended.

sentences.zh: 張儀復說哀王，哀王不聽。

translations.text: Zhang Yi again persuaded King Ai, but he wouldn't listen.

sentences.zh: 於是張儀陰令秦伐魏。

translations.text: Zhang Yi secretly ordered Qin to attack Wei.

sentences.zh: 魏與秦戰，敗。

translations.text: Wei fought Qin and was defeated.

translations.text: The next year, Qi again defeated Wei at Guanjin.

sentences.zh: 秦復欲攻魏，先敗韓申差軍，斬首八萬，諸侯震恐。

translations.text: Qin wanted to attack Wei again. First they defeated Han's Shen Chai army, beheading eighty thousand. The feudal lords were terrified.

sentences.zh: 而張儀復說魏王曰：「魏地方不至千里，卒不過三十萬。

translations.text: Zhang Yi again persuaded the King of Wei: 'Wei's territory is not even a thousand li square, with troops not exceeding three hundred thousand.'

sentences.zh: 地四平，諸侯四通輻湊，無名山大川之限。

translations.text: 'The land is flat all around, with roads from the feudal lords converging like spokes to a hub, without famous mountains or great rivers as barriers.'

sentences.zh: 從鄭至梁二百餘里，車馳人走，不待力而至。

translations.text: 'From Zheng to Liang is only two hundred li—chariots race and men run, arriving without effort.'

sentences.zh: 梁南與楚境，西與韓境，北與趙境，東與齊境，卒戍四方，守亭鄣者不下十萬。

translations.text: 'Liang borders Chu to the south, Han to the west, Zhao to the north, Qi to the east. Garrisons man the borders in all directions, with no fewer than ten thousand troops guarding the watchtowers and barriers.'

sentences.zh: 梁之地勢，固戰場也。

translations.text: 'Given Liang's geographical position, it is naturally a battlefield.'

sentences.zh: 梁南與楚而不與齊，則齊攻其東；

translations.text: 'If Liang allies with Chu but not Qi, Qi will attack from the east;'

sentences.zh: 東與齊而不與趙，則趙攻其北；

translations.text: 'If allied with Qi but not Zhao, Zhao will attack from the north;'

sentences.zh: 不合於韓，則韓攻其西；

translations.text: 'If not united with Han, Han will attack from the west;'

sentences.zh: 不親於楚，則楚攻其南：此所謂四分五裂之道也。

translations.text: 'If not close to Chu, Chu will attack from the south. This is what is called the path to being divided into four pieces.'

The next year, Qi again defeated Wei at Guanjin. Qin wanted to attack Wei again. First they defeated Han's Shen Chai army, beheading eighty thousand. The feudal lords were terrified. Zhang Yi again persuaded the King of Wei: 'Wei's territory is not even a thousand li square, with troops not exceeding three hundred thousand.' 'The land is flat all around, with roads from the feudal lords converging like spokes to a hub, without famous mountains or great rivers as barriers.' 'From Zheng to Liang is only two hundred li—chariots race and men run, arriving without effort.' 'Liang borders Chu to the south, Han to the west, Zhao to the north, Qi to the east. Garrisons man the borders in all directions, with no fewer than ten thousand troops guarding the watchtowers and barriers.' 'Given Liang's geographical position, it is naturally a battlefield.' 'If Liang allies with Chu but not Qi, Qi will attack from the east;' 'If allied with Qi but not Zhao, Zhao will attack from the north;' 'If not united with Han, Han will attack from the west;' 'If not close to Chu, Chu will attack from the south. This is what is called the path to being divided into four pieces.'

sentences.zh: 「且夫諸侯之為從者，將以安社稷尊主彊兵顯名也。

translations.text: 'Moreover, when the feudal lords form alliances, it is to secure their altars of soil and grain, honor their rulers, strengthen their armies, and make their names illustrious.'

sentences.zh: 今從者一天下，約為昆弟，刑白馬以盟洹水之上，以相堅也。

translations.text: 'Now the allies unite the world, swearing brotherhood, slaughtering white horses to make covenants on the Mian River to strengthen their bonds.'

sentences.zh: 而親昆弟同父母，尚有爭錢財，而欲恃詐偽反覆蘇秦之餘謀，其不可成亦明矣。

translations.text: 'Yet even true brothers from the same parents still fight over money and property. To rely on deception and betrayal, reviving the failed schemes of Su Qin—the impossibility of success is clear.'

'Moreover, when the feudal lords form alliances, it is to secure their altars of soil and grain, honor their rulers, strengthen their armies, and make their names illustrious.' 'Now the allies unite the world, swearing brotherhood, slaughtering white horses to make covenants on the Mian River to strengthen their bonds.' 'Yet even true brothers from the same parents still fight over money and property. To rely on deception and betrayal, reviving the failed schemes of Su Qin—the impossibility of success is clear.'

sentences.zh: 「大王不事秦，秦下兵攻河外，據卷、衍、［燕］、酸棗，劫衛取陽晉，則趙不南，趙不南而梁不北，梁不北則從道絕，從道絕則大王之國欲毋危不可得也。

translations.text: 'If Your Majesty does not serve Qin, Qin will send troops to attack beyond the Yellow River, occupy Juan, Yan, and Suzao, coerce Wei and take Yangjin. Then Zhao won't go south, and if Zhao doesn't go south, Wei won't go north. If Wei doesn't go north, the alliance routes will be cut. With the alliance routes cut, it will be impossible for Your Majesty's state to avoid danger.'

sentences.zh: 秦折韓而攻梁，韓怯於秦，秦韓為一，梁之亡可立而須也。

translations.text: 'Qin will defeat Han and attack Wei. Han fears Qin, so Qin and Han become one—Wei's destruction can be expected immediately.'

sentences.zh: 此臣之所為大王患也。

translations.text: 'This is what I fear for Your Majesty.'

'If Your Majesty does not serve Qin, Qin will send troops to attack beyond the Yellow River, occupy Juan, Yan, and Suzao, coerce Wei and take Yangjin. Then Zhao won't go south, and if Zhao doesn't go south, Wei won't go north. If Wei doesn't go north, the alliance routes will be cut. With the alliance routes cut, it will be impossible for Your Majesty's state to avoid danger.' 'Qin will defeat Han and attack Wei. Han fears Qin, so Qin and Han become one—Wei's destruction can be expected immediately.' 'This is what I fear for Your Majesty.'

sentences.zh: 「為大王計，莫如事秦。

translations.text: 'For Your Majesty's sake, nothing is better than serving Qin.'

sentences.zh: 事秦則楚、韓必不敢動；

translations.text: 'Serving Qin means Chu and Han will certainly not dare move;'

sentences.zh: 無楚、韓之患，則大王高枕而臥，國必無憂矣。

translations.text: No Chu Han calamity, then great wang high pillow lie, state certainly no worry.

'For Your Majesty's sake, nothing is better than serving Qin.' 'Serving Qin means Chu and Han will certainly not dare move;' No Chu Han calamity, then great wang high pillow lie, state certainly no worry.

sentences.zh: 「且夫秦之所欲弱者莫如楚，而能弱楚者莫如梁。

translations.text: "Moreover Qin desire weaken none like Chu, yet can weaken Chu none like Liang.

sentences.zh: 楚雖有富大之名而實空虛；

translations.text: Chu though have rich great name yet substance empty void;

sentences.zh: 其卒雖多，然而輕走易北，不能堅戰。

translations.text: Its troops though many, yet lightly flee easy north, cannot firm battle.

sentences.zh: 悉梁之兵南面而伐楚，勝之必矣。

translations.text: All Liang troops south face attack Chu, victorious certain.

sentences.zh: 割楚而益梁，虧楚而適秦，嫁禍安國，此善事也。

translations.text: 'Cede land from Chu to benefit Wei, harm Chu to help Qin, transfer disaster to secure the state—this is the way to serve well.'

sentences.zh: 大王不聽臣，秦下甲士而東伐，雖欲事秦，不可得矣。

translations.text: 'If Your Majesty does not listen to me, Qin will send armored troops east to attack. Even if you then wish to serve Qin, it will be impossible.'

"Moreover Qin desire weaken none like Chu, yet can weaken Chu none like Liang. Chu though have rich great name yet substance empty void; Its troops though many, yet lightly flee easy north, cannot firm battle. All Liang troops south face attack Chu, victorious certain. 'Cede land from Chu to benefit Wei, harm Chu to help Qin, transfer disaster to secure the state—this is the way to serve well.' 'If Your Majesty does not listen to me, Qin will send armored troops east to attack. Even if you then wish to serve Qin, it will be impossible.'

sentences.zh: 「且夫從人多奮辭而少可信，說一諸侯而成封侯，是故天下之游談士莫不日夜搤腕瞋目切齒以言從之便，以說人主。

translations.text: 'Moreover, alliance advocates use bold words but deliver little trust. Persuading one feudal lord brings a marquis's fief—so wandering persuaders all day and night clench their fists and glare, grinding their teeth to speak of alliance benefits, persuading rulers.'

sentences.zh: 人主賢其辯而牽其說，豈得無眩哉。

translations.text: 'Rulers admire their eloquence and are drawn by their words—how can they not be dazzled?'

'Moreover, alliance advocates use bold words but deliver little trust. Persuading one feudal lord brings a marquis's fief—so wandering persuaders all day and night clench their fists and glare, grinding their teeth to speak of alliance benefits, persuading rulers.' 'Rulers admire their eloquence and are drawn by their words—how can they not be dazzled?'

sentences.zh: 「臣聞之，積羽沈舟，群輕折軸，眾口鑠金，積毀銷骨，故願大王審定計議，且賜骸骨辟魏。」

translations.text: 'I have heard that accumulated feathers sink boats, gathered light breaks axles, many mouths melt metal, accumulated slander destroys bone. So I wish Your Majesty to carefully determine your plans, and grant me leave to retire from Wei.'

'I have heard that accumulated feathers sink boats, gathered light breaks axles, many mouths melt metal, accumulated slander destroys bone. So I wish Your Majesty to carefully determine your plans, and grant me leave to retire from Wei.'

sentences.zh: 哀王於是乃倍從約而因儀請成於秦。

translations.text: King Ai then abandoned the alliance and through Zhang Yi sought peace with Qin.

sentences.zh: 張儀歸，復相秦。

translations.text: Zhang Yi returned and again became prime minister of Qin.

sentences.zh: 三歲而魏復背秦為從。

translations.text: Three years later, Wei again abandoned Qin for alliances.

sentences.zh: 秦攻魏，取曲沃。

translations.text: Qin attacked Wei and took Quwo.

sentences.zh: 明年，魏復事秦。

translations.text: The next year, Wei again served Qin.

King Ai then abandoned the alliance and through Zhang Yi sought peace with Qin. Zhang Yi returned and again became prime minister of Qin. Three years later, Wei again abandoned Qin for alliances. Qin attacked Wei and took Quwo. The next year, Wei again served Qin.

sentences.zh: 秦欲伐齊，齊楚從親，於是張儀往相楚。

translations.text: Qin wanted to attack Qi. Qi and Chu were allied, so Zhang Yi went to become prime minister of Chu.

sentences.zh: 楚懷王聞張儀來，虛上舍而自館之。

translations.text: King Huai of Chu heard Zhang Yi was coming and prepared the finest guest quarters to house him personally.

sentences.zh: 曰：「此僻陋之國，子何以教之？」

translations.text: He said, 'This is a remote and backward country—what teachings do you bring?'

sentences.zh: 儀說楚王曰：「大王誠能聽臣，閉關絕約於齊，臣請獻商於之地六百里，使秦女得為大王箕帚之妾，秦楚娶婦嫁女，長為兄弟之國。

translations.text: Zhang Yi persuaded the King of Chu: 'If Your Majesty truly listens to me, close your borders and break relations with Qi. I will present the land of Shangyu, six hundred li square, so Qin women may become Your Majesty's broom-wielding concubines. Qin and Chu will exchange brides, becoming brother states forever.'

sentences.zh: 此北弱齊而西益秦也，計無便此者。」

translations.text: 'This weakens Qi to the north while benefiting Qin to the west—no plan could be better.'

sentences.zh: 楚王大說而許之。

translations.text: The King of Chu was greatly pleased and agreed.

sentences.zh: 群臣皆賀，陳軫獨弔之。

translations.text: All the ministers congratulated him, but Chen Zhen alone mourned.

sentences.zh: 楚王怒曰：「寡人不興師發兵得六百里地，群臣皆賀，子獨弔，何也？」

translations.text: The King of Chu was angry: 'I obtained six hundred li of land without raising troops or sending armies. All ministers congratulate me, yet you alone mourn—why?'

sentences.zh: 陳軫對曰：「不然，以臣觀之，商於之地不可得而齊秦合，齊秦合則患必至矣。」

translations.text: Chen Zhen replied: 'Not so. In my view, the land of Shangyu cannot be obtained, yet Qi and Qin will unite—disaster will certainly come.'

sentences.zh: 楚王曰：「有說乎？」

translations.text: The King of Chu said, 'Do you have an explanation?'

sentences.zh: 陳軫對曰：「夫秦之所以重楚者，以其有齊也。

translations.text: Chen Zhen replied: 'Qin's reason for valuing Chu is because Chu has Qi as an ally.'

sentences.zh: 今閉關絕約於齊，則楚孤。

translations.text: 'Now closing borders and breaking with Qi leaves Chu isolated.'

sentences.zh: 秦奚貪夫孤國，而與之商於之地六百里？

translations.text: 'Why would Qin covet an isolated state and give it six hundred li of Shangyu land?'

sentences.zh: 張儀至秦，必負王，是北絕齊交，西生患於秦也，而兩國之兵必俱至。

translations.text: 'Zhang Yi will return to Qin and certainly betray Your Majesty—this cuts off Qi relations to the north and creates trouble with Qin to the west. The troops of both countries will certainly attack together.'

sentences.zh: 善為王計者，不若陰合而陽絕於齊，使人隨張儀。

translations.text: 'A good plan for Your Majesty would be to secretly unite while openly breaking with Qi, sending someone to follow Zhang Yi.'

sentences.zh: 茍與吾地，絕齊未晚也；

translations.text: 'If they give us the land, breaking with Qi is not too late;'

sentences.zh: 不與吾地，陰合謀計也。」

translations.text: 'If they don't give us the land, we maintain the secret alliance.'

sentences.zh: 楚王曰：「願陳子閉口毋復言，以待寡人得地。」

translations.text: The King of Chu said, 'I wish you would shut your mouth and stop speaking, waiting for me to get the land.'

sentences.zh: 乃以相印授張儀，厚賂之。

translations.text: He gave the prime minister's seal to Zhang Yi and richly bribed him.

sentences.zh: 於是遂閉關絕約於齊，使一將軍隨張儀。

translations.text: Chu then closed its borders and broke relations with Qi, sending one general to follow Zhang Yi.

Qin wanted to attack Qi. Qi and Chu were allied, so Zhang Yi went to become prime minister of Chu. King Huai of Chu heard Zhang Yi was coming and prepared the finest guest quarters to house him personally. He said, 'This is a remote and backward country—what teachings do you bring?' Zhang Yi persuaded the King of Chu: 'If Your Majesty truly listens to me, close your borders and break relations with Qi. I will present the land of Shangyu, six hundred li square, so Qin women may become Your Majesty's broom-wielding concubines. Qin and Chu will exchange brides, becoming brother states forever.' 'This weakens Qi to the north while benefiting Qin to the west—no plan could be better.' The King of Chu was greatly pleased and agreed. All the ministers congratulated him, but Chen Zhen alone mourned. The King of Chu was angry: 'I obtained six hundred li of land without raising troops or sending armies. All ministers congratulate me, yet you alone mourn—why?' Chen Zhen replied: 'Not so. In my view, the land of Shangyu cannot be obtained, yet Qi and Qin will unite—disaster will certainly come.' The King of Chu said, 'Do you have an explanation?' Chen Zhen replied: 'Qin's reason for valuing Chu is because Chu has Qi as an ally.' 'Now closing borders and breaking with Qi leaves Chu isolated.' 'Why would Qin covet an isolated state and give it six hundred li of Shangyu land?' 'Zhang Yi will return to Qin and certainly betray Your Majesty—this cuts off Qi relations to the north and creates trouble with Qin to the west. The troops of both countries will certainly attack together.' 'A good plan for Your Majesty would be to secretly unite while openly breaking with Qi, sending someone to follow Zhang Yi.' 'If they give us the land, breaking with Qi is not too late;' 'If they don't give us the land, we maintain the secret alliance.' The King of Chu said, 'I wish you would shut your mouth and stop speaking, waiting for me to get the land.' He gave the prime minister's seal to Zhang Yi and richly bribed him. Chu then closed its borders and broke relations with Qi, sending one general to follow Zhang Yi.

sentences.zh: 張儀至秦，詳失綏墮車，不朝三月。

translations.text: Zhang Yi returned to Qin, pretending to lose his reins and fall from his chariot, not appearing at court for three months.

sentences.zh: 楚王聞之，曰：「儀以寡人絕齊未甚邪？」

translations.text: The King of Chu heard this and said, 'Is Zhang Yi thinking my break with Qi is not complete enough?'

sentences.zh: 乃使勇士至宋，借宋之符，北罵齊王。

translations.text: He sent brave warriors to Song, borrowing Song's credentials, to go north and curse the King of Qi.

sentences.zh: 齊王大怒，折節而下秦。

translations.text: The King of Qi was furious and humbled himself to submit to Qin.

sentences.zh: 秦齊之交合，張儀乃朝，謂楚使者曰：「臣有奉邑六里，願以獻大王左右。」

translations.text: With Qin and Qi allied, Zhang Yi appeared at court and told the Chu envoy: 'I have a fief of six li— I wish to present it to Your Majesty's attendants.'

sentences.zh: 楚使者曰：「臣受令於王，以商於之地六百里，不聞六里。」

translations.text: The Chu envoy said, 'I received orders from the king for six hundred li of Shangyu land, not six li.'

sentences.zh: 還報楚王，楚王大怒，發兵而攻秦。

translations.text: He returned and reported to the King of Chu, who was furious and sent troops to attack Qin.

sentences.zh: 陳軫曰：「軫可發口言乎？

translations.text: Chen Zhen said, 'May I now speak?'

sentences.zh: 攻之不如割地反以賂秦，與之并兵而攻齊，是我出地於秦，取償於齊也，王國尚可存。」

translations.text: 'Attacking is not as good as ceding land to bribe Qin, uniting troops to attack Qi—this gives land to Qin but takes compensation from Qi. Your Majesty's kingdom can still survive.'

sentences.zh: 楚王不聽，卒發兵而使將軍屈丐擊秦。

translations.text: The King of Chu wouldn't listen and sent troops with General Qu Gai to attack Qin.

sentences.zh: 秦齊共攻楚，斬首八萬，殺屈丐，遂取丹陽、漢中之地。

translations.text: Qin and Qi together attacked Chu, beheading eighty thousand, killing Qu Gai, and taking Danyang and Hanzhong.

sentences.zh: 楚又復益發兵而襲秦，至藍田，大戰，楚大敗，於是楚割兩城以與秦平。

translations.text: Chu again raised more troops to attack Qin, reaching Lantian. In a great battle, Chu was badly defeated. Chu then ceded two cities to make peace with Qin.

Zhang Yi returned to Qin, pretending to lose his reins and fall from his chariot, not appearing at court for three months. The King of Chu heard this and said, 'Is Zhang Yi thinking my break with Qi is not complete enough?' He sent brave warriors to Song, borrowing Song's credentials, to go north and curse the King of Qi. The King of Qi was furious and humbled himself to submit to Qin. With Qin and Qi allied, Zhang Yi appeared at court and told the Chu envoy: 'I have a fief of six li— I wish to present it to Your Majesty's attendants.' The Chu envoy said, 'I received orders from the king for six hundred li of Shangyu land, not six li.' He returned and reported to the King of Chu, who was furious and sent troops to attack Qin. Chen Zhen said, 'May I now speak?' 'Attacking is not as good as ceding land to bribe Qin, uniting troops to attack Qi—this gives land to Qin but takes compensation from Qi. Your Majesty's kingdom can still survive.' The King of Chu wouldn't listen and sent troops with General Qu Gai to attack Qin. Qin and Qi together attacked Chu, beheading eighty thousand, killing Qu Gai, and taking Danyang and Hanzhong. Chu again raised more troops to attack Qin, reaching Lantian. In a great battle, Chu was badly defeated. Chu then ceded two cities to make peace with Qin.

sentences.zh: 秦要楚欲得黔中地，欲以武關外易之。

translations.text: Qin pressed Chu for Qianzhong land, offering to exchange Wuguan.

sentences.zh: 楚王曰：「不願易地，願得張儀而獻黔中地。」

translations.text: The King of Chu said, 'I don't want to exchange land—I want Zhang Yi and will cede Qianzhong.'

sentences.zh: 秦王欲遣之，口弗忍言。

translations.text: The King of Qin wanted to send him but couldn't bear to say it.

sentences.zh: 張儀乃請行。

translations.text: Zhang Yi volunteered to go.

sentences.zh: 惠王曰：「彼楚王怒子之負以商於之地，是且甘心於子。」

translations.text: King Hui said, 'The King of Chu is angry at your betrayal over Shangyu land—he will surely vent his anger on you.'

sentences.zh: 張儀曰：「秦彊楚弱，臣善靳尚，尚得事楚夫人鄭袖，袖所言皆從。

translations.text: Zhang Yi said, 'Qin is strong and Chu weak. I am close to Jin Shang, who serves Lady Zheng Xiu. Whatever she says is followed.'

sentences.zh: 且臣奉王之節使楚，楚何敢加誅。

translations.text: 'Moreover, I carry Your Majesty's credentials to Chu—how dare Chu execute me.'

sentences.zh: 假令誅臣而為秦得黔中之地，臣之上願。」

translations.text: 'Even if they execute me and Qin gets Qianzhong, that would fulfill my greatest wish.'

sentences.zh: 遂使楚。

translations.text: He went to Chu.

sentences.zh: 楚懷王至則囚張儀，將殺之。

translations.text: The King of Chu imprisoned Zhang Yi and prepared to kill him.

sentences.zh: 靳尚謂鄭袖曰：「子亦知子之賤於王乎？」

translations.text: Jin Shang said to Zheng Xiu: 'Do you know how lowly you are to the king?'

sentences.zh: 鄭袖曰：「何也？」

translations.text: Zheng Xiu said, 'Why?'

sentences.zh: 靳尚曰：「秦王甚愛張儀而不欲出之，今將以上庸之地六縣賂楚，美人聘楚，以宮中善歌謳者為媵。

translations.text: Jin Shang said: 'The King of Qin loves Zhang Yi greatly and doesn't want to send him. Now he offers six counties of Shangyong land to bribe Chu, and sends beautiful women as brides, with palace singers as attendants.'

sentences.zh: 楚王重地尊秦，秦女必貴而夫人斥矣。

translations.text: 'The King of Chu values the land and respects Qin—Qin women will certainly be honored while you, madam, will be cast aside.'

sentences.zh: 不若為言而出之。」

translations.text: 'Better to speak on his behalf to save him.'

sentences.zh: 於是鄭袖日夜言懷王曰：「人臣各為其主用。

translations.text: Zheng Xiu then day and night spoke to King Huai: 'Ministers each serve their own lord.'

sentences.zh: 今地未入秦，秦使張儀來，至重王。

translations.text: 'Now the land has not yet gone to Qin, yet Qin sends Zhang Yi, showing great respect for the king.'

sentences.zh: 王未有禮而殺張儀，秦必大怒攻楚。

translations.text: 'The king has shown no courtesy but wants to kill Zhang Yi—Qin will certainly be furious and attack Chu.'

sentences.zh: 妾請子母俱遷江南，毋為秦所魚肉也。」

translations.text: 'I beg you and my son to move to south of the Yangtze, lest we become Qin's fish and meat.'

sentences.zh: 懷王後悔，赦張儀，厚禮之如故。

translations.text: King Huai regretted it, pardoned Zhang Yi, and treated him with the same generous hospitality.

Qin pressed Chu for Qianzhong land, offering to exchange Wuguan. The King of Chu said, 'I don't want to exchange land—I want Zhang Yi and will cede Qianzhong.' The King of Qin wanted to send him but couldn't bear to say it. Zhang Yi volunteered to go.
